required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Optical Transcutaneous Sensors of Capnia and Oxygenation
clinical_study.official_title: Validation of Optical Transcutaneous Sensors to Measure Capnia and Tissue Oxygenation

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims at validating new optical transcutaneous sensors to evaluate tissue capnia (CO2 partial pressure) and oxygenation (blood oxygen saturation) by comparing them to standard laboratory measurements (end tidal CO2 measurements and oxygen saturation by near-infrared spectroscopy).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: One single group will have simultaneous measurements of capnia and tissue oxygenation by the new sensors and by the standard laboratory sensors

primary_outcome.time_frame: Continuous measurement during the only experimental session (1 hour)
primary_outcome.description: Comparison of capnia values measured by the new sensors and the standard laboratory sensors

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Continuous measurement during the only experimental session (1 hour)
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of tissue oxygenation values measured by the new sensors and the standard laboratory sensors

arm_group.description: One single group of healthy subjects

intervention.intervention_name: Measurements of capnia and tissue oxygenation by optical transcutaneous sensors
intervention.description: Capnia and tissue oxygenation will be measured by optical transcutaneous sensors

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Males or females between 18 and 50 year old
- Individual having health insurance
- Individual able to provided informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index >27 kg/m²
- History of acute mountain sickness
- Chronic diseases know to be associated with high methemoglobinemia
- Active smoker (>3 cigarets/day)
- Alcohol consumption (>10g/day)
- Individual with high skin sensitivity due to skin diseases
- Mental disorders
